qas.question: What could cause the failure of a capacitor?

answers.text: when subjected to voltages or currents beyond their rating

qas.question: What can happen to capacitors used in high current applications?
What can happen to capacitors used in high energy capacitor banks?
What type of capacitors can generate soft x-rays?
What is one way to help minimize capacitor dangers?

plausible_answers.text: when subjected to voltages or currents beyond their rating

qas.question: What couldn't cause the failure of a capacitor?
What can't happen to capacitors used in high current applications?
What can happen to capacitors used in low energy capacitor banks?
What type of capacitors can generate hard x-rays?
What is one way to help maximize capacitor dangers?

context: Capacitors may catastrophically fail <a0_0><b5_0>when subjected to voltages or currents beyond their rating<b5_0/><a0_0/>, or as they reach their normal end of life. Dielectric or metal interconnection failures may create arcing that vaporizes the dielectric fluid, resulting in case bulging, rupture, or even an explosion. Capacitors used in RF or sustained high-current applications can <a1_0><b6_0>overheat<b6_0/><a1_0/>, especially in the center of the capacitor rolls. Capacitors used within high-energy capacitor banks can <a2_0><b7_0>violently explode<b7_0/><a2_0/> when a short in one capacitor causes sudden dumping of energy stored in the rest of the bank into the failing unit. <a3_0><b8_0>High voltage vacuum capacitors<b8_0/><a3_0/> can generate soft X-rays even during normal operation. Proper containment, fusing, and <a4_0><b9_0>preventive maintenance<b9_0/><a4_0/> can help to minimize these hazards.
